indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Increased, strengthened and expanded number of and capacity of human resources for government lead actors in understanding basic conflict handling mechanisms 2. Technical criteria developed to determine flashpoint conflicts using objective data collection and analysis 3. Government structures and systems developed for government lead actors for workload management and coordination 4. Increase in number and expansion in capacity of recovery/development activities in project areas reflecting enhanced conflict sensitivity 5. Acquired conflict handling knowledge and skills are reflected in government lead actors’ design and approach to targeting flashpoint conflicts 6. Increase in numbers and diversification of key stakeholders engaged by government lead actors in support of peace processes 7. Increase in number of coordinated linkages/projects/activities between recovery interventions and peace-led government processes 8. Inclusion of conflict sensitive practices in outcomes of recovery projects linked to peace processes

baseline.comment: • Government lead actors have received limited/ no technical training in conflict handling. • Government lead actors have received limited/ no institutional development support. • Targeted flashpoint conflicts determined based on political (not technical) criteria • Low levels of internal and external coordination by government lead actors with key stakeholders. • Limited range of approaches utilized to analyze and address flashpoint conflicts by government lead actors. • Peace conferences carried out as ‘one-off’ events with insufficient preparation/follow-up • Low levels of engagement of women and youth and other key stakeholders in government-led peace processes • Peace agreements achieved with some degree of political pressure • Government-led peace processes lack coordinated support to address identified causes of conflict • Post-conflict community needs identified without technical review or prioritization • Post-conflict recovery projects not implemented in conflict sensitive manner • Critical resources and lessons learned regarding conflict handling / conflict sensitivity not shared among key stakeholders

target.comment:
2014 Baseline: Project Output 1: Effective and sustainable Institutions are in place in support of community-level conflict resolution and prevention. 1. All members of the PC and SPPCC were trained in conflict transformation & peacebuilding 2. 2 (PC in BNS and SPPCC in SKS) 3. N/A 4. 86% of training participants surveyed reported using skills gained through JCRP trainings in the 3 months following training. (Source: Telephone surveys conducted with 25% of participants in 3 months after completion of trainings)
2014 Targets: Project Output 1: Effective and sustainable Institutions are in place in support of community-level conflict resolution and prevention 1. Target: All new members of the RPCM, PC and Native Administration trained on Conflict Mediation and DNH. 2. Target: 2013/14: 3 functioning conflict resolution mechanisms. 3. Target: 70% of community members rate RPCM and PC as either effective or very effective. 4. Target: 70% of community level peace actors trained by JCRP report using skills and tools gained through JCRP supported trainings in the 3 months following training.
2014 Baseline: Output 2: Immediate and emergent flashpoint conflicts mitigated through inclusive peace processes. 1. (2013): 94% of peace processes designed and implemented in 2013 continue to hold. 2. 25% of peace process participants represent vulnerable groups 3. N/A
2014 Targets: Output 2: Immediate and emergent flashpoint conflicts mitigated through inclusive peace processes. 1. Target: 80% of peace processes designed and implemented in 2013 continue to hold. 2. Target: 50% of peace process participants represent vulnerable groups. 3. Target: 80% of peace process participants report they are less likely to join state-wide fighting after the peace process.
2014 Baseline: Output 3: Targeted dividends delivered to communities in accordance to priorities identified during local processes Baseline (2013): 1. 67,800 beneficiaries (14,916 males, 21,018 females, and 31,866 ch

actual.comment:
2014 results: Output 1: 1. Feb 2014: No further trainings were provided in Q1. As the new RPCM in WKS was only established in March, training for the RPCM was re-scheduled for Phase II. 2. Feb 2014: With the establishment of the RPCM in March, 2014, there are now 3 functioning conflict resolution mechanisms. 3. Feb 2014: 43% (Of the 63 participants surveyed in 3 community consultations conducted in SKS and BNS, 27 or 43% indicated that they thought that the Government peacebuilding mechanisms in their state were “to some extent” or “very much” effective in contributing to conflict resolution in their communities. (Source: University of Khartoum Consultancy Report) 4. Feb 2014: 80% of participants trained in the reporting period reported using skills and tools gained through JCRP supported trainings in the 3 months following completion of training (Source: Follow up telephone surveys conducted with 24% of participants trained)
Output 2: 1. Feb 2014: 94% or 16/17 JCRP supported peace processes continue to hold six months after their conclusion. (Source: Government peacebuilding mechanisms, peace ambassadors and other key stakeholders) 2. Feb 2014: 62% - A total of 70 people participated in JRCP Peace Process Activities (Conferences and Workshops). Of these 22 or 31% were female with 22 or 31% under the age of 30. (Source: Participant registration sheets, Activity reports) 3. Feb 2014: 0% - Due to the political sensitivities referred to in Section V. on Challenges, this indicator was not monitored.
Output 3: 1. Feb 2014: 67,800 beneficiaries (14,916 males, 21,018 females, and 31,866 children) (Source: IOM reports) 2. Feb 2014: 90% reduction in conflict along the cattle migration corridor (Source: Police Records)

target.comment: Output 1:Government and community – led peace building initiatives supported to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful coexistence • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with core functions clearly defined • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with responsibilities and core functions clearly assigned • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with budgets allocated • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with action plans being implemented • Target: Increased capacity of Government partners to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful co-existence (10%) Output 2: Current and future local flashpoint conflicts are mitigated through inclusive peace processes. • Target: 70% of JCRP supported peace process holding after 12 months. • Target: 100 % of peace conferences carried out with the equal representation of the total number of conflicting parties. • Target: 50% of peace building training workshops, peace conference or dialogue participants from vulnerable groups (women, youth, elderly, persons with disabilities). Output 3: Local stakeholders are linked to high-level peace processes through dialogue and dissemination of information. • Target: 3 briefing session and dialogues conducted between local level and high level peace actors with the support of JCRP

actual.comment:
Output 1: Government and community – led peace building initiatives supported to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful coexistence • 3 Mechanisms are in place; the PC in BNS, the RPCM in WKS and the SPPCC in SKS (Source: Government Decrees) • The PC does have a budget allocated but the SPPCC and RPCM do not as yet. • All 3 peacebuilding mechanisms have action plans in place. • Repeat Assessments of Government partners perceived capacities to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful co-existence are due to take place in Q4 2015, the PC has 10% increase in graded score.
Output 2: Current and future local flashpoint conflicts are mitigated through inclusive peace processes. • 94% (or 16/17) of JCRP supported peace processes continued to hold after 12 months (Source: State Peacebuilding Mechanisms) •100 % of peace conferences carried out with the equal representation of the total number of conflicting parties. • One peace conference was held in June in SKS with 50% active participation from vulnerable groups.
Output 3: Local stakeholders are linked to high-level peace processes through dialogue and dissemination of information. • Three dialogues sessions between local level and high level peace actors with the support of JCRP were conducted in 2015: 1) 88 community peacebuilders, representatives from State-level mechanisms, and CSOs took part in the Peace Ambassador Forum held in Khartoum, March 2015, 2) during 3 days consultations in Khartoum in May 2015, more than 35 community peacebuilders from SKS, WKS, Abyei, BLN, and Darfur took part in a dialogue facilitation session and peacebuilding consultation at the University of Khartoum, 3) in September 2015, more than 400 people from SKS, WKS, BNS, Abyei and Darfur participated in the Sudan Peace Symposium (SPS) co-organized by UNDP/JCRP and the University of Khartoum. The participants included high-level government representation, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, State-lev

location.name: El Fasher

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1 Market monitoring information produced and used to boost livelihoods and local economies through trade in VC commodities. 1.2 Peacebuilding/Conflict mitigated: % change through increased personal investment in peace & cross tribal trade of VC commodities. 2.1 Trade routes map developed and produced across the 5 Darfur States; Related Value chain actors mapped. 5 State/interstate action plans identifying opportunities and constraints to trade by commodity developed by stakeholders in a participatory manner and adopted; 3.1 Average % increase of net annual income of reached SMEs, producer groups and households 3.2/3.3/3.4 % of women and vulnerable groups income and decision making participating in each value chains. 4.1 # of MSMEs opened/expanded 4.2 # of jobs created in VC commodities, by-products and spillover effects. 5.1 % income increase as a result of pricing transparency, access to MF and access to new markets. 5.2 % loan repayment rate to Micro-Finance Institutions (MFIs); 6.1 # direct linkages facilitated between producers and input suppliers and markets. 7.1 Analysis report on cereal trade in Darfur produced and recommendations to support rural livelihoods adopted and implemented by all relevant partners and stakeholders at different governance levels in Darfur;

baseline.comment: 1.1 No Market monitoring information produced and income survey to be conducted 1.2 No Peacebuilding/Conflict mitigated: % change through increased personal investment in peace & cross tribal trade of VC commodities. 2.1 No commodity maps exist; peace corridor maps are available although shifting. No State/interstate action plans identifying opportunities and constraints to trade by commodity developed by stakeholders in a participatory manner and adopted; 3.1 No Average HH net income at project’s first entry point 3.2/3.3/3.4 No income and decision making participation increase amongst women and vulnerable groups. 4.1 No MSMEs opened/expanded. 4.2 No jobs created in VC commodities, by-products and spillover effects. 5.1 No Income baseline in targeted VC communities 5.2 No access to MF and repayment rate 6.1 No direct linkages facilitated between producers and input suppliers and markets 7.1 No agreed strategy in place to support livelihoods of rural cereal producers. Limited export of Sudan cereals even when the export market is advantageous over the local market.

target.comment: 1.1) 15-30% average increase of net annual income of reached SMEs, producer groups and households annually. 1.2). Peacebuilding/conflict mitigation: 15%-20% change in number of respondents that report they have something to lose if violence breaks out e.g. loss of income. 2.1) Value chain maps for high value VC commodity(ies) targeted for development, constraints and opportunities mapped, including opportunities for women in a participatory manner and adopted. 3.1) 15-30% average increase of net annual income of reached SMEs, producer groups and households annually. 3.2) 50% women participation across value chains, 20% youth, 30% IDPs, returnees, and pastoralists. 3.3) 15-30% income increase amongst targeted women. 3.4) 15% change in the # of targeted women whom express increased decision making within HH and/or community/producer groups. 4.1/4.2) 500 new MSMEs opened/expanded and 1000 jobs created. 5.1/5.2) 25% increase in use of MF with minimum 60% repayment rate. 6.1) Minimum of one new linkage facilitated between producers and input suppliers and markets by each VC commodity. 7.1) Study recommendations applied to a Cereal Producers’ Livelihood Action Plan endorsed and promulgated by relevant local authorities, private sector partners, and UN and cereal producer associations.

actual.comment: 1.1) Monitoring surveys conducted in the 4 states (North, South, East, West Darfur) indicate that 76.4% of beneficiaries recorded between 10-50% increases of net annual income. The rest of beneficiaries (some 25.5%) reported more than 50% increases of net annual incomes. 1.2) UNDP was not given permission to conduct direct surveys relating the beneficiary perceptions on security. However, a rapid monitoring exercise conducted by DDRA indicates that 26% of value chain beneficiaries feared resumption of widespread violence due to its disruptive effect on their increasing business activities compared to 10 % at the beginning of this project. 2.1) The value chain analysis process has been initiated, still on-going and will be completed within the second quarter of 2015. The analyses involve updating the existing Value Chain Analysis conducted in 2010, scoping and identifying new value chain commodities, mapping of trade routes and flows, mapping of value chain actors and identifying key obstacles within identified commodity value chain. Mapping of Value Chain actors in the 5 states is being done as integral part of the comprehensive value chain analysis as stated above. The state/interstate plans have not yet been developed. These will be developed based on the specific challenges and obstacles identified as part of the outcome of the value chain analysis. The analyses are currently on-going and the plans will feed into similar UNDP value chain activities in the states. 3.1) Some 6,472 direct beneficiaries (SMEs, producer groups and households) who were assisted to improve production, processing, marketing of hibiscus, honey, groundnuts, and hides & skin commodities recorded average increase of 51.7% in annual incomes across all 4 value chains from $500 to about $758 3.2) Women constituted 53% of the participants (3430) in all value chains; 21% are youth, 40% of a project participants are IPDs, returnees and pastoralists. 3.3) Female beneficiaries who consist 53% of to

target.comment: 1.1 MMTA data collection and dissemination coverage expand by 25% 1.2 At least 5000 new beneficiaries have regular access to market information of which 40-50% are female. 1.3 85% of recipients regard the information as relevant and high quality. 1.4 At least 25% beneficiaries increased income due to access to MMTA information. 2.1 2010 Value Chain Analyses Reviewed and updated 2.2 At least 2 new commodities identified and analysed 2.3 New baseline assessment conducted conducted and established benchmark for M&E 3.1 15-30% increase in gross annual incomes of beneficiary SMEs, producer groups and households among which 50-60% are women and other vulnerable youth. 3.2 At least 50-60% of participants in value chain activities are women, IDPs/returnees, pastoralists and the youth across all value chains. 3.3 At least three new forward purchase contracts between producer groups and private sector purchasers. 3.4 At least 90% of aflatoxin test results between 0.5 and 3.5ppb against a minimum required quality threshold of 40ppb.

actual.comment: 1.1 Target exceeded. The MMTA data collection and dissemination coverage has increased by 46% from 50 at the end of 2014 to 73 markets. 1.2 Target exceeded. One edition of the market information bulletin was produced as of end of June 2015. Up to 6000 copies were circulated in English and Arabic as well as using online and SMS channels, reaching approximately 6000 additional stakeholders of which 45% are female. 1.3 A user perception survey is planned in December 2015 to gauge the relevance and quality of the MMTA and the extend of its coverage. 1.4 The user perception survey that is planned to take place in December 2015 will cover the beneficiaries report on their average income increase as a result of using the MMTA bulletin. 2.1/2.2 The value chain analysis process has been initiated and will be completed within the fourth quarter of 2015. The analysis involve updating the existing Value Chain Analysis conducted in 2010, scoping and identifying new value chain commodities, mapping of trade routes and flows, mapping of value chain actors and identifying key obstacles within identified commodity value chain. 2.3 Baseline survey is ongoing, using standardized questionnaires across 4 states of Darfur (WD, SD, ND and CD) with the help of 1 implementing partner and will be completed by the end of December 2015. 3.1 An assessment is planned for the last quarter of 2015 which will gauge the average income increase. 3.2 Target achieved. So far, approximately 52% of participants in value chain activities are women, IDPs/returnees, pastoralists and youth. 3.3 In order to finalize the three new forward purchase contracts between producer groups and private sector purchasers, 2 local hibiscus processors in Sudan have been contacted and discussions with DAL company on the promotion and marketing of groundnuts. In addition, a flower and beekeeping fair was organized in Khartoum where a beekeeping association from Darfur attended and explored forward purchasing opportuniti

indicator.title: Output Indicator

baseline.comment: - Crisis and Recovery Mapping and Analysis (CRMA) exercise completed in West Darfur state and reports and maps produced; but no village specific CRMA exercise - No Conflict assessment conducted in any of the four return villages in West Darfur State -Widespread destruction of livelihoods and productive assets in most villages in Darfur during the 9 years of the conflict; - No adequate support has been provided -Widespread destruction of basic community infrastructure,no adequate support has been provided. -No formal/ organised structures for coordinating / managing villages’ assets

actual.comment: 1.1) CRMA exercises were completed in four target villages and 21 key livelihoods and infrastructure interventions identified and implemented (see output 3). A gender disaggregated report including four (4) community resource maps and 4 development maps and plans were produced as an outcome of the CRMA exercises. Some 95% of the community resource persons involved in the process stated that they are now able to identify risks and needs and as well as identifying resources and opportunities to improve livelihoods and community development. 1.2) Conflict assessment and analysis were conducted in the four target villages. Key risk factors and conflict flash points were identified through the exercise. The exercise identified the risk of conflicts from the competition over limited natural resources and basic services such as water, fuelwood, grinding mills, grazing and agricultural land and conflict between nomads and sedentary farmers in the return villages. It also highlighted the distances to key resources and the risk to women. As a result appropriate interventions were identified, planned and implemented. 2.1) 769 vulnerable HHs in 4 villages now own and use productive assets such as donkey carts, treadle pumps, goats, and seeds and tools as a result of the Project. Details of the assets provided are listed in the table 1 and 2 above. 2.2) Some 513 HHs own and use fuel efficient stoves through the support of the Project. Out of these, 158 people have been trained as trainers in the production of fuel efficient stoves and in turn, they have trained up to 435 beneficiaries of which 86% were women. 3.1 Twenty One (21) community infrastructures were rehabilitated/ constructed and used. These include:  1 water pump constructed, 3 water pumps were rehabilitated, 2 hand dug- well constructed;  4 markets were rehabilitated;  7 grinding mills made available  1 oil extracting machine established and used;  1 storage facility was constructed  One building with 3 ro

baseline.comment: No functioning dialogue mechanism exist

target.comment: 1.1. 5 additional CBRM councils functional, including in Katila 1.2 50 % of community members have access to CBRMs 1.3: Project target 90% 1:4: Project target 80% 1.5: At least 1 representative of vulnerable groups in each CBRM 2.1: 5 community based management mechanisms for natural resources estab-lished 2.2: at least 5 social service infrastructure rehabilitated /newly built 2.3: 50 % of community members stating an increase in the number of interactions between diverse communities through basic services 2.4 At least 3 community social service infrastructure rehabilitated/ constructed. 3.1: 1 collective interactions of conflict resolution mechanisms with state and regional level mechanisms 3.2: 3 collective interactions of conflict resolutions mechanisms with higher level mechanism

actual.comment: Target 1.1: Four (4) new Peace Development Councils were established within the year: one in Idd el Fursan and one in Ku-bum, as well as two (2) sub committees in Kubum. Additional two PDCs will be established in Katilla in the Q1 2015. This brings to a total of 14 PDCS formed since the project started in January 2012. The capacity of PDC members was strengthened through 2 training workshops on conflict management and community planning. The trainings have built the confidence of the mem-bers and the councils are now operating with minimal backstop-ping from the DCRC team. Target 1.2 & 1.3: Within 2014, 100% of the disputes submitted to the PDCs were successfully resolved and settled. The PDCs resolved approximately 45 cases and became accessible by 100% of all the community members. Target 1.4: The project conducted a perception survey in Mukjar, Kubum and Idd Elfursan and as a result over 80% of commu-nity members who were interviewed reported that the project activities positively supported the restoration of trust and confi-dence. Target 1.5: Reported from PDCs: • Salamat tribe: 2 • Four tribe: 4 • Bani Halba: 5 • Women: 5 • Young male:2 • Young female: 2 • Bargo tribe: 1 • Hawsa: 2 • IDPs: 4 2.1: Internal review and workshops were conducted and 5 new areas for the community based management mechanisms for natural re-sources were identified. Through the comprehen-sive discussion with PDCs and the IPs, rehabilita-tion of 2 water points, 2 veterinary centres and construction of vegetable farms and water points were initiated and prioritised. 2.2: A total of 6 community improvement projects were completed in all three states within 2014. In Tawilla, implementation delayed due to the poor performance of the IP in North Darfur, new IP selected and the project made some good progress on the ground. With the no cost extension received, extending the duration of the project to the end of June 2014, the project succeeded to achieve 95% of this output. 2.3: Focus g

target.comment: 1.1 5 additional CBRM councils functional, including in Katila 1.2 50 % of community members have access to CBRMs of which at least 40% are female and vulnerable youth. 2.1 5 community based management mechanisms for natural resources established 2.2 At least 5 community social service infrastructure rehabilitated/ constructed 2.3 50 % of community members stating an increase in the number of interactions between diverse communities through basic services 3.1 3 collective interactions of conflict resolution mechanisms with state and regional level mechanisms 3.2 3 collective interactions of conflict resolutions mechanisms with higher level mechanism

actual.comment: 1.1 Target exceeded. A total of 6 CBRMs were established in Q1 and Q2 of 2015, including in Katila. 1.2 Target exceeded. CBRMs are accessible by the around 26,700 community members. This represents about 90 % of community members in the targeted communities. Perception survey conducted in Mukjar indicated that 90% of community members have access to CBRMS in the project target areas of which 60% are female. (source perception survey) 2.1Target achieved.Three (3) Joint Management Committees (JMC) have been established; one for managing the water well in Mukjar, one for managing the community farm of Kormondo and one for hand dug well in Birgi return village. Two more mechanisms are planned to be established before the end of the year. 2.2 Target exceeded. Total of seven Social service infrastructures have been established / rehabilitated including Two (2) new hand dug wells established in Bergi and Mukjar and one (1) hand dug well in Mukjar, One (1) Livelihood Centre Constructed in Mukjar and one Women Peace Centre at Katilla locality has been constructed, One (1) water station has rehabilitated in Damba village in Kubum Locality and One (1) bakery for food processing was established. 2.3 Target achieved. According to the perception survey conducted in September 2015, 84 % of the community members stated that there is an increase in the interaction between the communities due to establishment of the water points, vegetable farms, distribution of incomes generating sources and tools. 3.1 Target achieved. In 2015, 4 events for collective interaction of conflict resolution mechanisms included: One (1) consultative meeting was held with the Centre for Peace and Development of the University of Nyala and Three (3) workshops on Conflict analysis, Peace building and Conflict Transformation were conducted in Nyala, El Fasher and Zalingei. 3.2 Target achieved.Three Training of Trainer (TOT) workshops on Peacebuilding and Conflict Management and Transformation were cond

Output 1: 1.1. Percentage of households whose livelihood assets have increased in two years from project inception (e.g. livestock, agriculture production) disaggregated by type (for e.g. farmers, semi-nomads, & nomads, or displaced, non-displaced ) 1.2 Number of women, men, & youth that benefit of infrastructure rehabilitated/developed 1.3 Number of women, men, & youth employed in temporary labor intensive schemes 1.4 Number of savings and loans associations formed and active (number of women and men participating) 1.5 Number of CBOS established (CDC, producers group, infrastructure management committee, women’s associations, youth associations) (number of women and men participating) 1.6 % increase of net annual income reached women, men, youth, producer group type, household type; farmers, nomads, semi-nomads, displaced, & non-displaced) attributable to project activities 1.7 # % change in number of targeted women who express increased decision making power within households, communities and producer groups
Output 2: 2.1 % of resolutions implemented on natural resource based conflicts by the established mechanism 2.2 Improvement of perception of stakeholders with regard to peaceful resolution with focus on natural resource based conflicts (perception survey, gender disaggregated data) 2.3 Number of CBOs (CDC s, producers groups, women’s associations, youth associations) trained on natural resource management and conflict management per state (% of women trained). 2.4 Number of communities with a youth volunteers active in building capacity on natural resource management and integration with markets. 2.5 Number of youth volunteers trained on environmentally sustainable natural resource management (% of women).

baseline.comment: 1. To be established 2. To be established

target.comment: 1.1 70% of households have their livelihood assets increased in two years from project inception (e.g. livestock, agriculture production) 1.2 At least 70% of community assets rehabilitated/developed are linked with markets and value chains 1.3 24,000 men and women benefit of infrastructure rehabilitated/developed 1.4 350 people (at least 30% are women) are employed in temporary labour intensive schemes 1.5 Number of infrastructure rehabilitated/developed (by type) 1.6 At least 9 savings and loans associations formed and active (number of women and men participating) 1.7 9 producers groups established (number of women and men participating) 1.8 20 % increase of net annual income reached producer groups and households attributable to project activities 1.9 20 % change in income in the number of targeted women and change in number of targeted women who express increased decision making power within households, communities and producer groups. 2.1 70% of resolutions implemented on natural resource based conflicts by the established mechanism(disaggregated by type) 2.2 40 % increase in Perception of stakeholders with regard to security and peaceful resolution including natural resource based conflicts (perception survey, gender disaggregated data) 2.3 At least 9 CBOs, at least 5 of them are women groups, are trained on natural resource management; At least 300 CBOs members trained on conflict management (focus on natural resource based conflict) per state (at least 40% are women). 2.4 9 communities with a youth volunteer active in building capacity on natural resource management and integration with markets. 2.5 9 youth volunteers trained on environmentally sustainable natural resource management per state (% of women).

actual.comment: Project delayed, and all targets for 2014 have been transferred to 2015.

target.comment: 1.1 70% of households have their livelihood assets increased in two years from project inception (e.g. livestock, agriculture production) 1.2 At least 70% of community assets rehabilitated/developed are linked with markets and value chains 1.3 24,000 men and women benefit of infrastructure rehabilitated/developed 1.4 350 people (at least 30% are women) are employed in temporary labour intensive schemes 1.5 Number of infrastructure rehabilitated/developed (by type) 1.6 At least 9 savings and loans associations formed and active (number of women and men participating) 1.7 9 producers groups established (number of women and men participating) 1.8 20 % increase of net annual income reached producer groups and households attributable to project activities 1.9 20 % change in income in the number of targeted women and change in number of targeted women who express increased decision making power within households, communities and producer groups. 2.1 70% of resolutions implemented on natural resource based conflicts by the established mechanism(disaggregated by type) 2.2 40 % increase in Perception of stakeholders with regard to security and peaceful resolution including natural resource based conflicts (perception survey, gender disaggregated data) 2.3 At least 9 CBOs, at least 5 of them are women groups, are trained on natural resource management; At least 300 CBOs members trained on conflict management (focus on natural resource based conflict) per state (at least 40% are women). 2.4 9 communities with a youth volunteer active in building capacity on natural resource management and integration with markets. 2.5 9 youth volunteers trained on environmentally sustainable natural resource management per state (% of women).

actual.comment: 1.1 The result of this target will be measured at the end of the project 1.2 The development and rehabilitation of 41 community assets is currently ongoing. The result for this target will be evaluated by Q1 2016 1.3 An estimated 24,000 men and women are expected to benefit of the 41 community infrastructure currently being rehabilitated/developed. This number will be confirmed through the final monitoring survey. 1.4 1.5 41 community infrastructure is currently being rehabilitated/developed 1.6 So far, 4 savings and loans associations formed and are active 1.7 So far, 6 CBOs including 2 CDCs, 2 producers associations and 2 women’s group have been established (a total of 160 members with 68% women) 1.8 This result will be measured at the end of the year 1.9 This result will be measured through the final monitoring survey at the end of the project 2.1 5 CBOs have been trained on conflict management with a focus on natural resource based conflicts and 1 resolution has been agreed between farmers and herders to prevent clashed during the farming season 2.2 A perception survey will be carried out at the end of the project 2.3 So far, 5 CBOs, 2 of them are women groups, have been trained on natural resource management and at least 175 CBOs members trained on conflict management (focus on natural resource based conflict) per state (at least 38% are women). 2.4 9 communities have 2 community extension volunteers each, active in building capacity on natural resource management and integration with markets. 2.5 18 volunteers trained on environmentally sustainable natural resource management per state (50% women)

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Indicators (updated in 2014) 1.1 Number of baseline surveys, evaluations and reviews conducted; 1.2 % of Project Coordination Unit (PCU) and (SPCU) State Project Coordination Unit staff confident doing their jobs disaggregated by gender and state. 1.3. Plan to sustain the scheme in place 2.1 Number of young qualified graduates selected, trained and deployed disaggregated by gender and state. 2.2 % of volunteers satisfied with relevance and quality of training provided and applying at the field. 2.3 % of deployed volunteers who successfully graduate and receive certificates (disaggregated by gender and state) 3.1 Number of community members trained and Percentage of community members who feel enabled by training disaggregated by type of training, state, age and gender 3.2 Number of start-up micro-grants awarded and number of small businesses successfully started via the micro-grants disaggregated by state, gender and age of the business owner. 3.3 Number of small businesses successfully progressing 6 months after the start-up, disaggregated by gender of the business owner and age. 3.4 Number of environmental campaigns and cleanup exercises organised. 4.1 Number of graduation ceremonies and job fairs organised disaggregated by state; 4.2 % of deployed Youth Volunteers who successfully graduated disaggregated by state and gender. 4.3 % of deployed youth Volunteers employed after 6 months of training and graduation disaggregated by gender and state.

baseline.comment: Baseline: Darfur Youth unemployment estimated ≥ 40%

target.comment: Output 1: 1. Four (4) Schemes endorsed, established and operational: o South and East Darfur: 1 State-level Project Coordination Unit in the University of Nyala established o North Darfur: 1 Project Coordination unit in the University of El Fasher established in addition to the PCU o West and Central Darfur: 1 State-level Project Coordination Unit in the University of Zalingei established 2. 80 % of PCU’s and SPCUs’ staff who feel they are capable of doing their job Output 2: 3. 200 qualified young graduates selected and trained, disaggregated by gender and state o 95 young graduates in SED (40 % women) o 65 young graduates in ND (40 % women) o 40 young graduates in WCD (40 % women) 4. At least 80% of candidates satisfied with relevance and quality of the training provided 5. Youth Volunteers deployed: o South and East Darfur: 50 business volunteers and 15 environmental volunteers deployed o North Darfur: 30 business and 10 environment volunteers deployed o West and Central Darfur: 10 business and 5 environment volunteers deployed At least 80 % of volunteers deployed who feel they are capable of doing their job disaggregated by state and gender Output 3: 1. At least 80 % of community members trained (50 % women and youth) who feel trainings have enabled them to establish sustainable micro enterprises and: o At least 4,500 community members trained in Entrepreneurship (2,500 in SED, 1,500 in ND, 500 in WCD) o At least 1,500 community members trained in Natural Resource Management (700 in SED, 500 in ND, 300 in WCD) o At least 250 entrepreneurs trained in Mainstreaming of Environmental Sustainability (120 in SED, 80 in ND, 50 in WCD) o At least 1,125 community members trained in Business Idea Development (625 in SED, 375 in ND, 125 in WCD) o At least 4,500 community members trained in ASCA (2,500 in SED, 1,500 in ND, 500 in WCD) 2. At least 450 start-up micro-grants awarded for sound projects (250 in SED, 150 in ND, 50 in WCD) 3. At least 1500 businesses su

actual.comment:
Output 1: The targets achieved. One (1) PCU and 3 SPCUs established and operational in universities of El Fasher, Zalingei and Nyala. Government liaison officers seconded to the SPCUs. State level co-ordination fora established. A joint monitoring review conducted with PCU and SPCUs indicate that of 85% of their staff feel their capacity has improved through training, interaction and involvement in the programme. However, areas such as financial management, reporting and project management have been prioritised by PCU and the SPCUs as areas for any future capacity building.
Output 2: The targets achieved. 1-2. 205 volunteers were trained (M: 114, F: 91) and satisfied with the training.  95 young graduates in SED  65 young graduates in ND  45 young graduates in WCD 3-4. 139 volunteers comprising 126 Youth Volunteers (M: 65, F:61) and 13 Senior volunteers deployed:  SED: 51 business volunteers, 15 environmental volunteers and 7 Senior volunteers deployed  ND: 34 business, 11 environment volunteers and 4 Senior volunteers deployed  WCD: 10 business, 5 environment volunteers and 2 Senior volunteers deployed
Output 3: The targets achieved. 1-2. Cumulative total: 13,730.community members (M: 7,386, F: 6344) were trained on business and environment. Business including ASCA, micro-finance coaching and small business development training ND: 1,515 (M:910, F:618 )  WCD: 874(M:364, F:510 )Environment  SED: 1,003 (M: 552, F: 451)  ND: 585 (M:306, F:279)  WCD: 297 (M:158, F:139) 3, Start-up micro-grants/loan awarded for 158 sound projects as follows:  SED: 105 projects  ND: 40 projects  WCD: 13 projects 4, The activity could not be implemented due to budget constraints.
Output 5: The results were delivered under Output 3 1-2. The project was not able to implement these activities related to the targets 1-2 due to budget constraints. 3. Certificate award ceremony and job fair were organised in El Fasher, Nyala and Geneina. 139 youth and senior volunteers graduated

target.comment: 1.1 The Youth Volunteer Scheme reviewed through one independent evaluation and one baseline survey; 1.2 90% of PCU and SPCU staff feel capacitated and confident doing their jobs; 1.3 A sustainability strategy and plan for the Youth Volunteer scheme developed and adopted. 2.1. 80 youth volunteers from Phase 1 selected, trained on additional subjects and deployed; 100 new qualified young graduates selected, trained and deployed, disaggregated by gender and state; 80 Volunteers from phase 1 o 30Volunteers in SED (40 % female) o 30 young graduates in ND (40 % female) o 20 young graduates in WCD (40 % female). 100 New Volunteers o 45 young graduates in SED (40 % female). o 35 young graduates in ND (40 % female). o 20 young graduates in WCD (40 % female). 2.2 At least 90% of candidates satisfied with relevance and quality of the training provided and applying knowledge and skills at the field; 2.3 At least 90% of new youth volunteers deployed of successfully graduate of which 40% are female. 3.1 Approximately 5,000 (2000M/ 3000F) community members trained; of which 80% community members are satisfied with quality of training . Business Management Training (including entrepreneurship, ASCA management, business idea development) o SED: 1500 (600M/900F) o ND: 1,300 (520M/780) o WCD: 1,050 (420M/ 630F) Environment and Natural Resources o SED: 500 ( 200M/ 300F) o ND: 400 (160M/240F) o WCD: 250 (100M/150F) 3.2 At least 350 micro-grants awarded and 350 businesses successfully started/expanded via micro-grants; (100 in SED, 150 in ND, 100 in WCD) of which 50% are owned by women and 30% youth. 3.3 At least 270 of the small businesses started (60%) are successfully progressing 3 months after the start-up of which 60% are women and 30% youth. 3.4 At least 3 2 Environmental campaign and clean-up exercises organized under phase 1 (1 in El Fasher, 1 Geneina and 1 Nyala) 4.1 At least 3 Graduation ceremonies and jobs fairs organised (1 in SED, 1 in ND, 1 in WCD)

actual.comment: 1.1 The independent evaluation has been completed and the baseline survey is ongoing and will be finalized by the end of the year. 1.2 One PCU and 3 SPCUs were reactivated and are now operational. A perception survey with regards to the capacity and confidence of the staff will be conducted at the end of 2015. 1.3 The strategy is currently being developed by a consultant and will be finalized by the end of the year. 2.1. 59 youth from Phase 1 have been selected, trained and deployed. 150 new qualified young graduates selected and are under trained and deploy o 59 Volunteers from phase 1 (47% female) o 150 New volunteers (40% female) 2.2 Training is still ongoing and the evaluation results will be analyzed at the end of training 2.3 The training of the new volunteers is still ongoing and the volunteers are to be deployed in 2016 3.1 The training of the community members will be carried out in 2016 3.2 The micro-grants and business establishment will take place in 2016 3.3 The micro-grants and business establishment will take place in 2016 3.4 The environmental campaign will take place on 5 December, the International Volunteers Day 4.1 One graduation ceremony has been organized. The remaining two as well as the job fairs will be organized in 2016 4.2 This result will be measured at the end of the project in 2016 4.3 This result will be measured at the end of the project in 2016

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - RRR Sector operating effectively and improved coordination of ER activities - Knowledge and skills of UNDP and partners on ER enhanced through technical expertise and training - ER priorities reflected consistently across different humanitarian sectors and a coherent plan for the Sudan HWP strategic objectives of resilience and durable solutions in place

baseline.comment: - ER-gap Sector established, named the Recovery, Return and Reintegration (RRR) Sector - Capacity UNDP to meet expectations as sector lead nationally and in Darfur needs to be strengthened - Cross-sectoral prioritization of ER remains weak and uneven within current Humanitarian Planning and Coordination

target.comment: Output 1: Activity Result 1: ER plan/strategy for Darfur developed to respond to the relevant 2014 HWP Strategic Objectives. Activity Result 2: RRR Sector coordination operating effectively and the Sector Reponses Plan is implemented and monitored. Activity Result 3: RRR Sector Coordination is extended to Darfur

actual.comment: Activity Result 1: Target on track. In addition to the RRR sector, 6 additional sectors (the FSL, Education, WASH, NFI and Protection sector) have all reflected ER approaches in their humanitarian sector plans. Activity Result 2: Target on track. The coordination of ER activities has been improved and the effectiveness of the RRR sector increased. Activity Result 3: -The RRR sector was established in South Kordofan and in Q3/Q4 of 2015, this will be further expanded to Darfur.

target.comment: Output 1: 1.1 At least 5 sectors have ER priorities reflected in them 1.2 Strategy paper on ER, resilience and durable solutions developed for Sudan 1.3 Twelve RRR sector coordination meetings conducted in Khartoum and sector established in Darfur 1.4 Four UNDP dedicated staff for RRR recruited and UNDP’s capacity as sector lead strengthened

actual.comment: Activity Result 1: Target achieved. In the 2015 Humanitarian response plan (HRP), 5 sectors have reflected ER approaches in their humanitarian sector plans and during consultations in preparation of the 2016 HRP all sectors have agreed to reflect ER approaches in their sector plans and all are aiming to identify better linkages between humanitarian response and longer-term recovery in Sudan. However the overall 2016 HRP has been delayed and is not yet finalized. Activity Result 2: Target achieved. The RRR sector has build capacity in key staff from Humanitarian Aid Commission and Darfur Regional Authorities in support of a national-owned Durable Solutions (DS) Strategy for IDPs in Sudan in line with international standards. Strategies for ER & DS have been developed and fed into the 2016 HRP consultation meetings. Activity Result 3: Target on track -The RRR sector has conducted 11 sector meetings in Khartoum and has planned one more meeting for December 2015. Due to delay in recruitment, the sector in Darfur has not been established. However, consultation meetings have taken place in Darfur in preparation of the establishment of the RRR sector. Activity Result 4: Target achieved - Three UNDP dedicated staff have been recruited. As per the plan, the fourth staff, for UNDP's capacity to lead ER coordination, has been realized through the short-term recruitment of an Early Recovery Advisor to the HC/RC

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: % of community members sampled stating that trust & confidence is restored % of tribal/civil society leaders sampled agreeing to a common and/or collaborative approach on how to address root causes of conflict

target.comment: 90 % of community members sampled stating that trust & confidence is restored 94 % of tribal/civil society leaders sampled agreeing to a common and/or collaborative approach on how to address root causes of conflict

actual.comment: 88% of respondents answered that they feel that trust and confidence among parties has been restored. Furthermore, 92% of respondents feel that conflicts and disputes have decreased. This perception has changed in a positive way since the previous survey, when only 80% responded that conflicts and disputes have decreased. 95% report that they think there is an agreed approach on how to address root causes of conflict. It should be noted that although this question was aimed at community leaders/tribal leaders/members of CBRM, most interviewees, regardless of involvement, contributed an answer.

target.comment: 90 % of community members sampled stating that trust & confidence is restored 85 % of tribal/civil society leaders sampled agreeing to a common and/or collaborative approach on how to address root causes of conflict

indicator.title: Output Indicator

baseline.comment: 1. 1,700 ex-combatants disarmed and demobilized in ESPA areas. 2. N/A

target.comment: 1.1.At east 100 ex -combatants desegregated by sex( 50% male and 50% female ) are provided with livelihood assistance, micro credit and livelihood assistance. 1.2. At least 15-20 % of DDR participants are earning livable income through reintegration services in Blue Nile, South Kordofan and Central Sector. 2.1.At least two training workshops for government partners in small arms control and management conducted at national level. 2.2. Three communities are provided with socio economic infrastructure in support of social services provision , conflict resolution and local economic regeneration. 2.3. Three hundred (300) men and women(50%-50%) trained in sustainable natural resource management, income generation, conflict resolution, gender equality and women empowerment, community security and small arms control. 3.1. Programme operational guidelines, Exit Strategy, Community based M&E Strategy drafted and validated by SDDRC 3.2. 3 Specialized trainings for SDDRC / MOI and National NGOs 3.3. Networking of DDR NGOs established and information briefing on new programme conducted 4.1. Effective and efficient Staff administration and operational support guaranteed. 4.2.Field operations scaled down in line with programme closure procedures and available resources with responsibilities transferred to State Department and Institutions

actual.comment: 1.1. By the end of 2014 Approximately 72% (26,112) out of the 36,251 demobilized fighters (approximately 17% women) have received reintegration support. 1.2.1.At least 75% former combatants are satisfied with the projects and 13-15% are able to earn income from the reintegration projects. 1.2.2 Beneficiary Tracer Survey report disseminated with key SDDRP programme stakeholders and one final review workshop conducted. 2.1. The lessons learned workshop report is currently being finalized by the consultant. 2.2. Three pilot projects were completed in target locations. 2.3. Training for 300 beneficiaries conducted, and one case study report on One Man Can (OMC) gender product was compiled and disseminated. 3.1 A guidance note on community based reintegration drafted and shared with the key partner SDDRC. The community based reintegration and CSAC further transformed to Community 3.2.1Based Stabilization. The exit strategy was not initiated with SDDRC given the transition of the programme . SDDRC remains as a key partner for the new programme and restructured the units according to the new realities. 3.2.2.Training on Community Based Reintegration, Monitoring and Evaluation, Joomla and DRR were conducted for SDDRC staff apart from day- to-day guidance and mentoring. 3.2.3. The national NGOs were engaged with the program directly through implementation of Pilot CBR projects. Additionally the contracted national NGOs continue to maintain supporting one another through the initial inception of pilot projects and the remaining reintegration process. Briefing on the new programme will be conducted once funding available for stabilization project in 2015. 4.1.in order to maintain the relevance and effectiveness of the programme and its closure, the appropriate technical, operational and management support were initiated. 4.2. The implementation of Pilot projects facilitated to

target.comment:
1. Reintegration of 26,112 completed and MIS database handed over to the SDDRC-national counterpart.
2. Prepare Final Project Review report and evaluation conducted
3. Initiate project Audit (if applicable)
4. Ensure that all financial transactions are in Atlas (Based on final report from the Implementing Partners)
5. Notify the Head of Unit or the DCD (P) on the operational completion of the project
6. Operationally close the project (and Award if applicable)
7. Conduct final project budget revision and sign final Annual Work Plan
8. Negotiate with Donor on refund/reallocation of cost-sharing balances at the fund-project-donor level (very last step prior to designating the project as financially complete)
9. Ensure project accounts are closed

actual.comment: SDDRP 2015 project closure target from 1-9 achieved

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Technical Working Group and DCPSF Steering Committee Meetings held regularly. - DCPSF Technical Secretariat has the human and technical resources. - Call for Proposals is successfully managed and new projects/partners are contracted

target.comment: - Technical Working Group and DCPSF Steering Committee Meetings held on a quarterly basis - DCPSF Technical Secretariat has the human and technical resources to successfully implement DCPSF goals and objectives - Call for Proposals is successfully managed and new projects/partners are contracted - Biannual, Annual, and Quarterly reports are prepared, approved and distributed to stakeholders and partners

actual.comment: - Technical Working Group and Steering Committee Meetings were held - Progress towards full staffing of the DCPSF Technical Secretariat was made through the recruitment of an M&E Analyst; other recruitments are ongoing. - The call for proposals was completed and new projects contracted. - All required reports were produced and distributed to stakeholders and donors

target.comment: - Technical Working Group and DCPSF Steering Committee Meetings held on a quarterly basis - DCPSF Technical Secretariat has the human and technical resources to successfully implement DCPSF goals and objectives - Gender strategy is operationalized - Call for Proposals is successfully managed and new projects/partners are contracted - Impact assessment of community based reconciliation mechanisms is completed - Biannual, Annual, and Quarterly reports are prepared, approved and distributed to stakeholders and partners

actual.comment:
- Technical Working Group and DCPSF Steering Committee each met twice to date, with additional SC meeting planned for December.
- 3 M&E analysts joined in the 1st quarter. Head of Technical Secretariat (July) and Communications and Reporting Officer (June) also recruited and on staff.As of July 2015, DCPSF Technical Secretariat is fully staffed.
- Implementation of gender strategy continues. A draft implementation plan has been developed and relevant components are being shared with lead implementers for review and action.
- Call for proposals made in July, with 98 proposals submitted. Appraisal committee recruited and the steering committee endorsed the recommendations on 8 November.
- Procurement of services for conducting an impact assessment has been initiated.
- Q1 and Biannual reports compiled and distributed on time. Q3 report is currently in progress.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1 Locality plans linked to the state Strategic Plan 1.2 The State budget linked to planning framework 1.3 State Macro-economic policy formulated 2.1 -Enactment of state financial laws 2.2 Amendment to state Local Government laws to clarify fiscal roles between Federal, state and localities 2.3 State administrative, accounting and finance regulations established 3.1 Institutionalized budget policy analysis and management function 3.2: Planning office established 3.3: MoLG coordinates capacity development for localities 3.4: Roles for public planning and expenditure management clarified 4.1: Number of laws reviewed 4.2: Number of policies reviewed 4.3: Level of harmonisation in institutional mandates and functions 5.1 Regular rhythm of policy dialogue under the Forum; 5.2 Regular rhythm of engagement with donors; 6.1: implementation structures established 6.2: Key Staff Recruited 6.3: Implementation agreements secured 6.4: Programme financing secured

baseline.comment: 1.1 - GFS classification has only been introduced in RSS 1.2 - all the three states do not have an institutionalised budget policy function and the budgets are not guided by macro-economic analysis 1.3 - revenue predictions are inadequate and unreliable (up to 60% shortfalls) severely affecting the predictability of budget implementation 2.1 None of the 3 state has the required laws and regulations for financial and procurement management 2.2 Gaps in fiscal relations between state and local government level leading to overlapping or confusing roles in revenue and expenditure management and accountability 2.3 Gaps in fiscal relations between state and federal government leading to confusing roles in fiscal policy management 3.1 Institutional roles for budget policy analysis and management are not clearly defined leading to overlap and gaps in implementation 3.2 there are no locality planning units in the states of Kassala and Gedaref while in RSS only 5 of the 10 localities have locality plans 3.3 in all the 3 states the public expenditure policy management function is lacking 3.4 organisational and financial management skills are low across the states leading to planning and budget formulation 4. lack of a coordinated legal, policy and institutional reform programme; lack of policy coordination mechanism; overlapping legal frameworks and institutional mandates; low public service out put 5. Eastern Sudan Forum has not worked as a forum in mobilising 3 states towards objectives of the ESPA 6.- Programme implementation structures not established

target.comment: 1. 30% of total LDF/F seed fund raised or pledged 2. 1 Annual review of 50% of local development plans 3. Institutional linkage with the Institute of Strategic Planning established 4. 1 Leadership training courses/modules developed 5. 1 study on the State of Youth in Eastern Sudan completed 6. 1 political economy analysis for local governance in Eastern Sudan conducted 7. 3 technical experts deployed for community capacity

actual.comment: 1. Thirteen projects were successfully completed in Kassala State and counterpart (Government and Community) contribution of 75% to LDF funded projects was raised. 2. Conducted meetings to review the community participation in local development planning 3. The Strategic Planning Council in Gedarif State has been engaged in preparation of a Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper. 4. Analysis and identification of community leadership capacity and challenges among community leaders completed and a menu of competencies needed by community leaders as base for the leadership training modules. 5. Structured process of mainstreaming youth issues in public policy initiated: Through consultative meetings, consensus, legitimacy and public value on the need for an evidence based Youth development programame in Eastern Sudan 6. Political Economy Analysis conducted in Kassala State in partnership with the state Ministry of Finance and the State Council for Strategic planning. 7. 4 technical experts were deployed to Kassala and Gedarif States to support the process of initiating the locality development plans.

target.comment: - 2.1.1. at least 2 training programmes in core local governance functions - 2.1.2. legislative forums conducted and 2 strategies reviewed - 2.2.1. at least 120 staff 80 males and 40 female on planning) trained within the planning department in the state ministries of finance in the East and South Kordofan - 2.3.1. Number of 60 youth (30 F/30M) engaged in training on local governance development issues - A.1.1.1. Finalized and approved AWP 2015 - A.1.2.1. At least four case stories developed and shared each quarter - A.1.2.2. At least 8 visits paid to various location of the project A.2.1.1 risks and issues updated quarterly for the project .3.2.1. LGDPEM Project experience produced by experts

actual.comment: - 2 training workshop conducted in Gedarif State for new government executives on core local governance functions - 65 staff were trained on project management in Gedarif State (35 males and 30 female) represented from Ministry of Finance. - 70 youth (4 F/30M) were trained in Kassala State on electronic data management - 40 staff (22 males and 18 females) were trained on SPSS data analysis for in Ministry of Finance in Gedarif State. - 6 staff from East Sudan (Kassala, Red Sea and Gedarif states) participated in a study tour in Ethiopia, and were exposed to the planning, revenue mobilization and public finance management in Ethiopia. - 4 monitoring visits paid to various location of the project. - Project risks and issues updated in ATLAS - Impact study of the LGDPEM Project conducted in Kassala state as a case study.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. # of staff trained on Human Development Report (HDR) processes and report writing techniques 2. Number of key stakeholders reviewing the first draft. 3. Number of NHDR produced, and Number of policy discussion that occurs as result of NHDR advocacy activities.

baseline.comment: 1. There is ministerial decree issued in 2005 to establish the steering committee for HDR, however none of the members had a formal training on NHDR processes 2. NHDR has never been produced.

target.comment: 1. Advocacy campaign for the NHDR at national and sub national levels including parliamentarian, Journalists and States Walis 2. Printing and distribution of the report for wider distribution. 3.Partnership with the Society Studies Centre for Human development related studies including Futuristic study, Sudan society status report and Darfur peace.

actual.comment:
1. The promotion of the key messages in the report took place in collaboration with the Ministry of Welfare and Social Security (MoWSS). 2. Printing and distribution of the report for wider distribution did not take place. However the project has already executed a workshop targeting the media. A plan is prepared for carrying out around 2-policy discussions in August. 3. Partnership with Society Studies centre made, status of youth in the Sudanese community reflected; concept paper is written and secondary data is collected to serve the background synthesis.
In addition to the following achievements: • Darfur peace building and development strategic directives; concept paper is written, secondary data is collected and primary data collection also have been completed. • Sudan Prospective Study (2014-2040): concept paper is drafted. Scientific committee has critically reviewed the paper. A consultation meeting with the Decision Support Centre in the Minister Council held to further discuss the draft; an international consultant was recruited to administer a number of 3 workshops to explain the context of prospective study.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. No of adaptation practices from the five pilot agro-ecological zones integrated into policy or programmes. 2.Number of institutions supported to develop capacities to respond to climate change risks and plan for adaptation. 3.No of knowledge products produced including a national guide book of best practices.

baseline.comment: 1.Available national food security policy did not not integrating climate change related issues. 2.Communities are autonomously adapting to climate variability; added pressures on livelihoods due to climate change have rendered current coping mechanisms in effective and Mal-adapted to long-term changes. 3.Inadequate awareness, technical capacities and knowledge to make informed decisions regarding adaptation to climate change.

target.comment: 1. Dissemination of results and good climate change adaptation practices to inform policy change for integrating climate change in state level planning 2. Measures to improve animal production and crop productivity introduced to build communities resilience and improve livelihoods 3.Enhance the capacities of the communities and technical staff in the states in the area of extension and M & E, and revolving fund .

actual.comment: 1. A systematic compilation of experiences is a pre-requisite to successful adaptation strategies including horizontal and vertical knowledge transfer, replication and up-scale. Lessons learnt and best practices report prepared and documented to inform policy decisions 2.Diversified, drought resistant varieties of crops and animal breeds introduced and adopted by the targeted communities in 4 targeted states through cropping of drought resist varieties are introduced SD, RN and Gedarif; fodder bailing & improvement, supplementary feeding. Results have shown that 200 households in North Kordofan have benefitted from the fattening and milk production pilots through supplementary feeding. The preliminary results have indicated an increment of 244 gm per day for the sheep and 1.3 litres of milk for goats. 3. The awareness of women groups was enhanced in the area of the importance of forest cover in combating desertification and the impacts of climate change in the River Nile state villages. Four training workshops were held in the four targeted villages to build the capacities of the women groups in CBOs organization and management. Project teams and coordinators were trained on Tracking and Measuring Adaptation impact

target.comment: The project is operationally closed

actual.comment: The project is operationally closed

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
% of community members sampled stating that trust & confidence is restored
· Outputs Indicators:
· Number of community based resolution mechanisms (CBRM) functioning (target 72)
% of community members stating an increase in the economic interventions between diverse communities
% of community members stating an increase in the number of interactions between diverse communities
· through basic services (health initiatives, schools, vocational education, water)

target.comment:
90 % of community members sampled stating that trust & confidence is restored 85 % of tribal/civil society leaders sampled agreeing to a common and/or collaborative approach on how to address root causes of conflict
Output 1: Effective community-level conflict resolution and prevention platforms in Darfur are in place Number of community based resolution mechanisms (CBRM) functioning (target 72) 70 % of community members with access to CBRM 85 % of community members stating satisfaction with CBRM 60 % of the number of cases submitted that are successfully addressed 56 % of community members stating an increase in the percentage of cases submitted and successfully addressed
Output 2: Cooperation between communities enhanced through shared livelihood assets and income generating opportunities and activities Number of community initiatives that deliver collaborative livelihoods & income generating opportunities (including joint labour, trading, community youth and women) (52) Number of new/re-established markets that enable diverse communities to interact/cooperate (15 additional) 85% of community members stating an increase in the economic interventions between diverse communities

location.name: El Fasher
location.description: seat of a first-order administrative division

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Increase in revenue collection 2. Number of institutions at state and locality level with computerized payroll system 3. Number of SSP reviewed and prioritized for three states

baseline.comment: 1. Local revenue too low amounting to only 15% (ND), 20% (SD) and 3.5% (WD) of total revenue receipts in 2009 (ND) and 2010 (SD & WD). 2. No Standard guidelines for revenue collection and reporting in place. 3. Budget departments facing difficulties to apply the GFS as it was imposed from the national Government without provision of requisite training. 4. Payroll is done manually resulting in errors and huge payroll arrears. 5. Strategic planning is still at its infancy and therefore needs strengthening.

target.comment:
1. Revenue collection & Reporting 1.1 100 booklets/guidelines developed & distributed to localities 1.2 10 teams applying GFS system in selected localities for the year.
2. Budget preparation & Management 2.1 20 line ministries & 10 selected localities prepare GFS conform budget. 2.2 90 staff from line ministries and pilot localities trained on GFS.
3. Accounting & reporting systems developed 3.1 40% at line ministries & 20% at localities level decrease in reporting inconsistencies 3.2 20 line ministries & 10 selected localities apply the adopted GFS system after training.
4. Payroll Management & Control 4.1 5 State Ministries of Finance equipped with computerized payroll system 4.2 5 payroll audits conducted
5. Planning & local development fund 5.1 SSP 2012-2016 reviewed for three states & new SSP prepared for 2 states. 5.2 Guide for Strategic Planning Developed & 100 copies distributed 5.3 200 staff trained

actual.comment: 297 participants were exposed to principles of improved revenue collection and reporting The guidelines on financial procedure and budgeting processes were produced in West Darfur and were distributed to stakeholders. 40% at line ministries and 20% at localities level decreased in reporting inconsistencies 20 line ministries and 10 selected localities applied the adopted GFS system Three State ministries equipped and automated payroll system functional. The total number of staff trained in various aspects of project planning, management and evaluation was 226 (79 females and 147 males), exceeding the annual target of 200. In West Darfur, a payroll audit team has been established and payroll audit conducted

target.comment:
Output 1 10% increase in local revenue collection 100 booklets/guidelines developed & distributed to localities 10 teams applying GFS system in selected localities for the year
Output 2 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities prepare GFS conforming budget 90 staff from line ministries and pilot localities trained on GFS.
Output 3 20% of line ministries and 20% of localities level decrease in reporting inconsistencies 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities apply the adopted GFS system
Output 4 5 State Ministries of Finance equipped with computerized payroll system and routinely using it 1 audit conducted 20% decrease in payroll arrears
Output 5 Guide for strategic planning developed & 100 copies distributed 200 staff at state and locality levels trained on strategic planning process.

actual.comment: Two preliminary audits were undertaken in West and South Darfur

location.name: Kassala
location.description: seat of a first-order administrative division

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:  Number of trainees’ enrolments and graduates from vocational training centers.  Number of beneficiaries with increased income from acquired new skills.  Improvement of quality two training centers and sustainability of vocational training delivery in target areas.  Increased productivity and profitability for pastoralists and farmers  Number of farmers and pastoralist connected to markets  Coverage of agricultural, veterinary and animal extension services in target areas expanded  Number and capacity of community based organizations delivering livelihoods services improved  Number of new microfinance clients increased  Number of beneficiaries receiving business and financial skills training in the target area.  Quality of service provider performance in microfinance delivery improved  Gender assessment conducted and report compiled  # of institutions trained in gender sensitive programming  # women with increased life skills  # of beneficiaries trained in the “One Man Can” manual  # of locality plans formulated  # of sectors within locality governments with clearly defined responsibilities for sector and all employees  Locality Administrations’ ability to identify and implement development priorities improved  # of basic services sustainably provided through localities or CBOs increased

baseline.comment:
 Low levels of vocational skills and training of refugees and host communities in the target areas  Vocational training only available in Girba Camp and Girba town, 281 beneficiaries received training in 2011  Average production under rain-fed cultivation 2-3 sacks of Sorghum/Sesame per feddan  Business opportunities and entrepreneurship capacities within groups in the target areas need to be improved.  Limited access to microfinance Limited women's active participation in political and economic sphere in east Sudan.
 No Locality Plans developed  Limited ability to identify and implement development initiative

target.comment:
Output 1: (1) 1,000 trainees enrolled for vocational training in Girba and Fashaga localities and (2) 75% of the enrolled trainees graduated. (3) At least 1000 of the commutative graduate will have improved income from acquired new skills, of which at least 25% women (4) At least 500 graduates develop management and business plans for vocational-oriented SMEs businesses.
Output 4: (1) Average production for farmers rain fed sorghum 1.9 sacks/feddan and irrigated sorghum 7.8 sacks/feddan (2) 1,000 farmers/ pastoralists households linked to markets for agricultural and pastoral commodities (3) 55 para-vets trained in livestock management [20 basic training and 35 advanced training] (4) 120,000 animals vaccinated (5) please include the total then the breakdown ( Three agricultural extension services accessed by 2,240 farmers and pastoralists [700 farmers trained and supported in water harvesting ; 1,000 trained in animal extension and 540 trained in cropping practices])  (6) 2,400 people supported in income generating projects.  (7) 2,300 members are trained and establish home gardens.
Output 5: (1) 150 savings groups formed (2) 3,000 microfinance beneficiaries’ capacity and skills in business management improved of which at least 50 % women. (3) 90% Attendance rate (4) Cumulative savings of SDG 900,000 for the active saving and lending groups (5) 5,000 microfinance members with loans (value of loans) (6) 70% started own business, IGA, and SMEs. (7) 90% Loan Repayment Rate (8) 500 defaulters (10% of members with loans will default on repayments)
Output 7: (1) 30 persons from 05 IPs trained in gender sensitive programming (2) 75% of trained staff are satisfied with quality and effectiveness of training in gender sensitive programming (3) 700 women trained on life skills and supported in income generation projects (4) 75% of trained women start own business, IGA or small scale enterprises (5) 03 social events hosted jointly by refugees and

actual.comment:
Output 1: No implementation progress – programme suspended during 2014
Output 4: No implementation progress – programme suspended during 2014
Output 5: No implementation progress – programme suspended during 2014
Output 7: Implementation of approved activities for 2014 were not initiated because of suspension
Output 8: No implementation progress – programme suspended during 2014

iati-activity.description: The project will assist in developing, revising and updating a National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan (NBSAP) for Sudan and anchored into national development frameworks.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: The inclusion of measurable biodiversity conservation and sustainable use targets into the sectoral planning frameworks e.g. agriculture, forestry, livestock, tourism, trade, travel and transport, fishery and water.

baseline.comment: 2013 baseline: No targets available in order to measure the loss of biodiversity and ecosystem functionality in the agriculture, forestry, tourism, trade, travel and transport and fishery sectors

target.comment: --National Biodiversity targets developed -- A strategy for resource mobilization for the implementation of the NBSAP produced -- National frameworks for NBSAP implementation is developed; -- The Sudan’s NBSAP strategy is fully updated, -- An effective, user-friendly and easily-updatable CHM web that will effectively share information nationally, regionally and globally developed. The web will also work in collaboration with the CHM of the Secretariat of the CBD, to ensure that lessons and information are disseminated globally. -- Draft BD strategy updated

actual.comment: -- National biodiversity targets in place in response to the global Aichi Targets -- Resource mobilization strategy for for the implementation of the biodiversity strategy developed -- National frameworks for NBSAP developed -- Update of the National Strategy for biodiversity in under process. CHM web for Sudan in place and relevant stakeholders trained by international experts from Morocco. -- Sudan CHM web established and linked to the CBD secretariat one. A service room for CHM assigned at the Higher Council for Environment and Natural Resources premises and three computers provided to be used by people. -- CBD Strategy is ongoing

target.comment: National CBD Strategy for Sudan has been finalized and presented to the Council of Ministers for Endorsement.

actual.comment: The final draft of the National Strategy is finalized and discussed in a consultative meeting. It has been presented to the Council Ministers by the Minister of Environment and been endorsed by the Council. The strategy has been forwarded to the GEF secretariat.
