indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Indicators Output1: 1.Number of government staff members o responsible for aid coordination functions whose capacities have significantly been improved 2.Improvement in organizational performance in units of MoFNE responsible for aid coordination (the organizational performance will be monitored through a capacity review in 2014) Indicators Output2: 1. Percentage of programmes included in SAID for which regularly updated M&E data is available 2. Percentage of projects included in SAID for which regularly updated M&E data is available
Indicators Output3:
1. Change in levels and quality of coordination of aid policy between government concerned departments (will be monitored through conducting aid policy coordination studies) 2. Establishment of sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forum on aid policy and coordination

baseline.comment:
Baseline output1: 1. Following the government restructure in 2012, the government Directorates responsible for aid management and coordination have been organized according to new institutional and coordination set up in the government. 2. Capacities of government officials responsible for aid management and coordination needs to be further developed to manage aid coordination after government restructuring 3. No comprehensive capacity assessment has been carried out for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination. 4. No comprehensive capacity development plan has been developed and implemented for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination
Baseline Output2: 1. SAID project module has been completed successfully. 2. SAID Fund Expectation module has been completed. 3. SAID programme and aid effectiveness modules have not been completed 4. Aid M&E and information systems are not integrated and harmonized
Baseline Output3:
1. Government aid policy coordination between relevant directorates of the MoFNE (budget, policies, aid management and coordination and development directorates) needs strengthening especially after the government restructuring 2. There are no sufficient aid dialogue and coordination structures including government and development partners 3. A draft Sudan Aid Strategy has been formulated

target.comment:
Output 1: Indicator: Number of government staff members responsible for aid coordination functions who are trained in aid management and coordination
Target: 110 key and junior government staff members responsible for aid coordination and management trained in Aid Management and Coordination
Output 2: Indicators: 2.1. % of programmes included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.2. % of projects included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.3. Inclusion of data on development loans in SAID 2.4. Online availability of SAID
Targets: 2.1. 100% of programmes included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.2. 100% of projects included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.3. SAID includes data on development loans 2.4. SAID available online
Output 3: Indicators: 3.1. The review of aid strategy by government and development partners and endorsed 3.2. Development of Terms of Reference and membership for sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forums on aid policy and coordination
Targets: 3.1. The Aid Strategy Document reviewed by government and development partners and endorsed 3.2. Terms of Reference and membership for sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forums on aid policy developed and coordination established

actual.comment:
Output 1: Indicator: Number of government staff members responsible for aid coordination functions who are trained in aid management and coordination
Target: 110 key and junior government staff members responsible for aid coordination and management trained in Aid Management and Coordination Result: 260 key and junior government staff members responsible for aid coordination and management trained in Aid Management and Coordination Output 2: Indicators: 2.1. % of programmes included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.2. % of projects included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.3. Inclusion of data on development loans in SAID 2.4. Online availability of SAID
Targets: 2.1. 100% of programmes included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.2. 100% of projects included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.3. SAID includes data on development loans 2.4. SAID available online
Results: 2.1. 80% of programmes included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.2. 80% of projects included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning M&E system 2.3. Inclusion of data on development loans has not been completed 2.4. SAID will be available online in the first quarter of 2016
Output 3: Indicators: 3.1. The review of aid strategy by government and development partners and endorsed 3.2. Development of Terms of Reference and membership for sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forums on aid policy and coordination
Targets: 3.1. The Aid Strategy Document reviewed by government and development partners and endorsed 3.2. Terms of Reference and membership for sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forums on aid policy developed and coordination established
Results: 3.1. The Aid Strategy Document reviewed by government and development partn

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -- Change in government commitments, resource allocations and planning for the environmental and disaster risk management

actual.comment: -- National tasks forces formed and are contributing with the national consultant in the development of the national strategy -- Technical capacities and knowledge of the National Task Forces and their associated departments enhanced on DRR methodologies; modern technologies and interpreting data from remote sensing, satellite imagery and GIS -- National DRR strategy is under development -- Consultative workshops organized for the early warning committee to define and put strategies for EWS

-- A number of consultative meetings with relevant stakeholders, academia and community held to discuss and agree on the methodology and structure of the national strategy -- Development of the national strategy started; national consultant recruited for this purpose. -- A team of consultants recruited to conduct risk assessment; produce risk profile for Sudan -- Remote Sensing Department of Khartoum University contracted to conduct the Risk Analysis and prepare Sudan Risk profile -- Hazard maps for floods prepared -- Early Warning equipment procured for the Early Warning Authority and Civil Defence Council

location.name: El Fasher
location.description: seat of a first-order administrative division

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1) Market monitoring information produced and used to boost livelihoods and local economies through trade in VC commodities 1.2) Peacebuilding/Conflict mitigated: % change through increased personal investment in peace & cross tribal trade of VC commodities 2.1) Trade routes map developed and produced across the 5 Darfur States 2.2) Related value chain actors mapped. 2.3) # of state/interstate action plans identifying opportunities and constraints to trade by commodity. 3.1) Average % increase of net annual income of reached SMEs, producer groups and households 3.2) % of women and vulnerable groups participating in each value chain value chains 3.3) % of income increase amongst targeted women. 3.4) % change in the # of targeted women whom express increased decision making within HH and/or community/producer groups. 4.1) # of MSMEs opened/expanded 4.2) # of jobs created in value chain commodities, by-products and spillover effects. 5.1) % income increase as a result of pricing transparency, access to MF and access to new markets. 5.2) % loan repayment rate to Micro-Finance Institutions (MFIs); 6.1) % income increase contributed to by articulated state/interstate mitigation measures implemented disaggregated by sector. 6.2) # of new SMEs and jobs generated as a result of value chain development (by-products or spill over invalue chains and surrounding communities). 6.3) # direct linkages facilitated between producers and input suppliers and markets. 7.1) Analysis report on cereal trade in Darfur produced and recommendations to support rural livelihoods adopted and implemented by all relevant partners and stakeholders at different governance levels in Darfur

baseline.comment: 1.1 ) A Quarterly Market Monitoring Bulletin for West and North Darfur is available. Anticipated expansion to South and Central Darfur produced by DDRA with TA from Tufts-FIC to identify how livelihoods and the economy can be supported through trade, and to identify peace-building opportunities through trade. No Bulletin available in the East. 1.2) No reporting system for loss of income due to conflict 2.1) Baseline Analysis and mapping conducted in 2010. 2.2) No commodity maps exist; peace corridor maps are available. 2.3) No interstate plans in place 3.1) Average HH net income of $500 at project’s first entry point 3.2) 10% income and decision making participation increase amongst women. 3.3/3.4) 30 % vulnerable groups participation 4.1/4.2) Limited/no BDS hubs exists limiting access to information for business development and expansion. Low capacity of government entities to provide even high demand services e.g. vet and agriculture due to no/limited budgets. 5.1) Average annual household income about $500 in targeted VC communities 5.2) 2% access to MF and repayment rate 6.1/6.2/6.3)The business enabling environment for value chain commodities is poor: e.g. groundnut and livestock taxes are high with multiple state and local taxes (formal and informal) 7.1) No agreed strategy in place to support livelihoods of rural cereal producers. Limited export of Sudan cereals even when the export market is advantageous over the local market. Millet and sorghum price monitoring by DDRA in North and West Darfur in 2013 and FEWS NET Market Monitoring will be used as the price baseline; however a boost cannot be expected until harvest/sale 2014.

target.comment: 1.1) Market bulletins produced and dispersed 1.2) Peace building/conflict mitigation: 15%-20% change in number of respondents that report they have something to lose if violence breaks out e.g. loss of income. 2.1) Value chain maps for high value VC commodity(ies) targeted for development, constraints and opportunities mapped, including opportunities for women in a participatory manner and adopted. 3.1) 15-30% average increase of net annual income of reached SMEs, producer groups and households annually. 3.2) 50% women participation across value chains, 20% youth, 30% IDPs, returnees, and pastoralists. 3.3) 15-30% income increase amongst targeted women. 3.4) 15% change in the # of targeted women whom express increased decision making within HH and/or community/producer 4.1/4.2) 500 new MSMEs opened/expanded and 1000 jobs created. 5.1) 15-30% average increase of net annual income of reached SMEs, producer groups and households. 5.2) 25% increase in use of MF with minimum 60% repayment rate. 6.1) 5-30% average increase of net annual income of reached SMEs, producer groups and households contributed to by BEE measures implemented. 6.2) 500 new MSMEs opened/expanded and 1000 jobs created. 6.3) Minimum of one new linkage facilitated between producers and input suppliers and markets by each VC commodity. 7.1) Study recommendations applied to a Cereal Producers’ Livelihood Action Plan endorsed and promulgated by relevant local authorities, private sector partners, and UN and cereal producer associations

actual.comment: 1.1) Market bulletins produced and dispersed. Monitoring surveys conducted in North, South, East, and West Darfur indicate that 97.8% of the recipients ranked the bulletins between medium and high quality and 69.6% of beneficiaries stated that they received them on regular basis (quarterly). The surveys further indicated that 69.1% of beneficiaries stated that the information received contributed positively to the marketing of their products which helped them achieve good prices for their products. As a result, 76.4% of beneficiaries recorded between 10-50% increases of net annual income as a result of the MMTA activities . The rest of beneficiaries (some 25.5%) reported more than 50% increases of net annual incomes. 1.2) UNDP was not allowed by HAC to conduct direct surveys relating the beneficiary perceptions on security. However, a rapid monitoring exercise conducted by DDRA indicates that 26% of value chain beneficiaries feared resumption of widespread violence due to its disruptive effect on their increasing business activities compared to 10 % at the beginning of this project. 2.1/2.2/2.3 2.1) The value chain analysis process is still on-going and will be completed within the second quarter of 2015. The analysis involves updating the existing Value Chain Analysis conducted in 2010, scoping and identifying new value chain commodities, mapping of trade routes along commodity corridors, mapping of value chain actors participating within identified commodity corridors as well as identifying challenges and obstacles to trade within commodity corridors and determine modalities to ease bottlenecks. The Terms of reference for the analysis have been reviewed, and a new plan have been developed. Data collection tools and the scoping protocols have been developed pending the start of the process. 3.1) Some 6,000 direct beneficiaries (SMEs, producer groups and households) were assisted to improve production, processing, marketing of hibiscus, honey, groundnuts, and hides

target.comment: Project Not Active.

indicator.description: 1. Number of managerial, administrative technical personnel whose capacity is developed 2. Labour based coordination unit is in place with clear action plan and ToR 3. Number of workshops, conferences, meetings, etc., organized and held with governmental bodies, private sectors companies related to temporary job placement 4. Number of institutions, centers contracted for training purposes 5. Number of labourers trained in business skills, vocational skills, life skills, and occupational health and safety 6. Percentage of trained individuals who have passed examination. 7. Number of business/ labour groups formed 8. Percentage of business/labour groups active 3 months after formation and awarded contract and/or job placed 9. Number and length of assignments taken on by business/labour groups

baseline.comment: 1. Existing Poverty Unit at the MOHRDL 2. MOHRDL previous experience in Labour Intensive Programs

target.comment: 1. Labour based Coordination Unit is established and well integrated within MOHRDL 2. Human technical capacity of MOHRDL personnel working in Labour Coordination Unit is developed 3. Coordination of Labour based works is carried out in a proficient manner.

actual.comment:
1. A ministerial decree issued with the establishment of the labor based coordination unit within the ministry (MOHRDL) structure. 2. Comprehensive capacity development plan developed for the coordination unit technical team. On job training is ongoing by an international technical advisor for the project. 3. Head of labor based coordination unit started round of negotiations and partnerships with various sector leads within the government and private sector including Sudanese contractors association, Social Development foundation Higher council for vocational training.
In addition to: Five staff are appointed and deployed on full time bases to assume their technical functions as prescribed on the unit TOR, and Training courses on English language, project management, proposal writing, web based database establishment and fund raising are conducted to the unit team and successfully passed.

target.comment: 1. Labour based Coordination Unit established and well integrated within Ministry of Labour & Administrative Reforms 2. Human technical capacity of Labour based Coordination Unit staff is developed 3. At least 2000 unskilled youth (700 male & 300 female) trained in different skills 4. 75% of youth (50% male & 25% female) absorbed into permanent employment

actual.comment: 1. Labour based Coordination Unit is structured with 5 posts and assigned staff, namely Training and Curriculum Development; Policy, Planning and Research; Communications, Advocacy & Resource Mobilization; and Youth Employment & Business Advisory plus Head of the Unit. 2. A comprehensive Capacity Development Training plan has been developed which started by in – house trainings on Project Management and Microsoft Excel fundamentals. Technical trainings on the required areas of specialization for the Unit staff. i.e. Communication, Curriculum Design, Research and Youth Employment is to start by Jan 2016. 3. 1251 youth received training on waste management and entrepreneurship skills. 4.100 youth are offered permanent jobs at Waste Management Sector

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: ‎1.Number of small-‎holder rain-fed ‎farmers and ‎pastoralist ‎households with ‎access to MF or ‎MF/WII products ‎ ‎ ‎2.Domestic finance ‎committed to the ‎relevant institutions ‎to monitor extreme ‎weather and climate ‎change

baseline.comment:
‎1. MFIs/Insurance companies ‎have limited capacity to provide ‎tailored financial services for ‎smallholder rain-fed farmers and ‎pastoralists. Current products are ‎too generalized and do not ‎consider flexible payment cycles ‎and reasonable compensation ‎criteria. MFIs/Insurance ‎companies have not found means ‎to access the remote, rural areas ‎‎(e.g., mobile units), organize the ‎farmers/pastoralists nor mitigate ‎their associated risks. As a result, it ‎is common that ‎farmers/pastoralists use informal ‎lending services. ‎BASELINE:93,500 with access to ‎MF, 0 with access to MF/WII; ‎
‎2.Existing budget plans do not ‎have sufficient funds to maintain ‎and operate environmental ‎monitoring infrastructure. ‎BASELINE: Annual O&M budgets ‎for weather and climate ‎monitoring institutions are ‎approximately, MoWRE: USD ‎‎223,000, RSA: USD 100,000 ‎and SMA: 300,000.‎ ‎1.Currently, weather and ‎climate monitoring ‎coverage in the target ‎States is limited. Most ‎equipment is manual and ‎up to 40% of equipment ‎is not-functional. A ‎BASELINE of what is ‎operational includes in ‎the 6 target States ‎includes the following:‎ Meteorological stations: ‎‎28 manual, 32 automatic Hydrology equipment: 17 ‎water level, 4 manual and ‎‎1 automatic flow meters‎ Rain gauges:‎ ‎98 manual‎
‎2.There are existing ‎regional and community-‎based EWS initiatives for ‎food security, however, a ‎national alert system ‎concerned with extreme ‎hydro-meteorological ‎phenomena is lacking. ‎ There is also a limited ‎understanding of ‎technical weather/climate ‎information jargon (e.g., ‎alerts are not translated ‎into all national dialects). ‎There is also no ‎formalized ‎communication ‎mechanism for alerts and ‎weather/climate ‎information. End-users ‎cannot provide feedback ‎to improve the ‎communication process.‎ BASELINE ‎% Women who receive ‎EWS alerts‎ states: 5%‎ ‎% Men who receive EWS ‎alerts/CI in target states: ‎‎10%‎
‎3. BASELINE Bulletins are currently ‎produced se

target.comment: 1.1 50 % increase in population who have access to improved Early Warning System/Climate Information 1.2 8% of Women (farmers and pastoralists equally) received EWS alerts/CI in targeted states & 15% of Men (farmers and pastoralists equally) received EWS alerts/CI in targeted states.

actual.comment:
1.1 0% achieved. Due to the late start of the project (October 2014). Time spent on recruitment of staff, identification of project's technical committee and organization of the first project Board meeting. 1.2: 0% achieved for the same reasons above.
Due to that the targets (which was pasted form the project document, was moved to 2015.

target.comment: 1.1: 50 % increase in population who have access to improved Early Warning System/Climate Information of whom at lease 50% are Women (farmers and pastoralists equally) received EWS alerts/CI in targeted states.

actual.comment:
Procurement made during 2015 for outcome (1) devices and equipments are 30,7% of the WS (Automatic and manual), 98% of the rain gauges have been completed out of the 60% planned for 2015 for the institutional capacity of the SMA. %100 of the water level devises equipment have been purchased represents the whole procurement of the project for these items for the institutional capacity of MoWRIE by procuring Procurement of 8 water level meters to be placed, 3 manual, hydrological stations and 2 acoustic Doppler flow meters (ADCP).
1.1 The stations installed serving a total of 10,000 in River Nile covering 82,9% of the target population, of whom 3,300 are women (33%) and 15 rain gauges covered all the target villages. In North Kordofan state, all the target community are in Bara locality within the limits of the automatic station. the station serves 4,756 population, 1,198 are women representing (25,2%) In White Nile state the station has been installed in aldoaim locality where it serves 1,973 of the population 888 of them are women (45%) In South Darfur state, 32 units of the rain gauges have been delivered and 24 have been installed in 24 out of 26 target communities, and no automatic weather station have installed. The total coverage with the rain gages is (62%) representing 45,000 out of the total population of the target communities of South Darfur (71,564). In Kassala and Gedarif states the weather stations have not installed during this reporting period, and the rain gauges installed where 2 out of 42 delivered to the state office of SMA (4.8%) in Kassala and no unit installed in Gedarif. The total number of the rain gauges installed and function is 41 out of 162 planned for 2015 in the six states represents (25.3%). The total target population in the six states are 96,082, of them 25,386 (26.2% women) are covered with the target climate monitoring devices represents the farmer group have access to the climate/weather monitoring services in the target s

indicator.description: a) Number of environmental and social guidelines developed for implementing wind farms b) Extent to which RE policies and regulations are adopted and enforced. d) Number of individuals and organisations trained and capable of supporting activity in the Sudanese wind market. e) Number of educational tours conducted to wind farms in neighbouring countries f) Number of MW power generated from wind energy. g) Number of wind farms developed in Sudan.

baseline.comment: a) Renewable energy master plan b) Preliminary wind measurements have been carried out as well as some feasibility assessments based on those measurements. c) wind atlas based on extrapolation of world data with high probability of inaccuracy. d) Limited exchange of experiences with neighbouring countries with established wind farm like Egypt and Ethiopia. e) Number of MW power generated from wind energy. f) Number of wind farms developed in Sudan.

target.comment: A) Wind atlas based on extrapolation of world data with high probability of inaccuracy. B) 3 tours to neighboring countries with established wind farm and power purchase agreements like South Africa, Egypt and Ethiopia. C) 5 MW power generated from wind energy. D) EIA updated to include the impacts on Migratory Souring Bird (MSB) in Dongla and Red Sea.

actual.comment: A) Training on Wind Atlas Software was conducted for 20 engineers from all stakeholder institutions. B) 8 engineers from the project and other institutions participated in three tours to South Africa, Uganda and Jordon. C) 0 MW power generated from wind energy due to lack of the baseline project. D) EIA update completed in both Dongla and Red Sea

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
% of community members sampled stating that trust & confidence is restored
% % of tribal/civil society leaders sampled agreeing to a common and/or collaborative approach on how to address root causes of conflict

target.comment: 90 % of community members sampled stating that trust & confidence is restored 94% % of tribal/civil society leaders sampled agreeing to a common and/or collaborative approach on how to address root causes of conflict

actual.comment:
2014 Achievements based on 2014 Annual Report (includes survey results from Feb 2015.)
88% of community members sampled in February 2015 stating that trust & confidence is restored 95% of tribal/civil society leaders sampled in perception survey conducted in February 2015 agreeing to a common and/or collaborative approach on how to address root causes of conflict
Output 1: Effective community-level conflict resolution and prevention platforms in Darfur are in place 312 community based resolution mechanisms (CBRM) functioning (total cumulative) 83% of community members surveyed in February 2015 with access to CBRM 85% of community members surveyed in February 2015 stating satisfaction with CBRM 88% of the number of cases submitted that are successfully addressed 74% of community members surveyed in February 2015 stating an increase in the percentage of cases submitted and successfully addressed
Output 2: Cooperation between communities enhanced through shared livelihood assets and income generating opportunities and activities 355 community initiatives that deliver collaborative livelihoods & income generating opportunities 22 new/re-established markets that enable diverse communities to interact/cooperate (15 additional) 76% of community members surveyed in February 2015 stating an increase in the economic interventions between diverse communities
Output 3: Cooperation between competing communities over access to natural resources and basic social services increased 285 community based management mechanisms for natural resource (disaggregated by activity: water, pasture, forest reserves, migration routes, minerals, etc) 23 migratory routes demarcated / cleared /rehabilitated through communal consensus 61 additional areas of restoration of communal pasture/ fodder/communal forests 53% of community members surveyed in February 2015 confirming communal consensus around restoration of migratory routes/pasture/fodder/communal forests 332 social service infrastru

target.comment: 90 % of community members sampled stating that trust & confidence is restored 85 % of tribal/civil society leaders sampled agreeing to a common and/or collaborative approach on how to address root causes of conflict

actual.comment: Perception survey covering programming active in 2015 will be conducted in Q1 2016, thus results are not yet available. Also, these results will be reported in 00064738.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1.1 # of criminal justice forums established and frequency of meetings 1.2 # justice strategy plans roll out for the prosecutor 1.3 # of joint training sessions conducted on the human rights approach for justice sector officials 1.4 # of joint training sessions conducted on strategic planning processes for justice sector officials 1.5 # of joint training sessions on budgeting processes conducted for justice sector officials # of legal aid provider clients (individual and communities) disaggregated by gender (% of women) assisted with legal aid counselling 1.2.1: # of refresher courses for GoS prisons officers on human rights approach to prisons management and # of training courses for newly recruited prisons officers for a total of # participants 1.2.2: # of water tanks constructed to address water needs of selected prisons 1.2.3: #of vocational and livelihood skills training workshops established and type of tools and equipment procured 1.3.1. .#of capacity development trainings, including strategic planning conducted for police officers 1.3.2. #civilian oversight mechanisms in place 1.4.1: #of capacity development trainings conducted to Sudan National Human Rights Commission staff and key stakeholders 1.4.2: New committee in Darfur established and strategic priorities for Darfur defined 1.5.1. # of relevant government officials have improved their knowledge in human rights, and improved the implementation of Sudan obligations under human rights treaties 1.5. 2. Number of capacity building workshops to support revision of laws in line with Sudan’s record regarding harmonization of legislation with international obligations 1.5.3: UPR Action Plan reviewed/finalized, with attribution/development of specific sets of indicators and timelines 2.1.1: % of people expressing high confidence in and easy access to rule of law institutions disaggregated by gender disaggregated by state
2.1.2: : # of legal aid provider clients (individual and communities) disaggreg

baseline.comment: 1. Two criminal justice forums established at regional level (one in Darfur and one in eastern Sudan) and quarterly meetings held 2. 100 complaints received and no data on caseload age 3. No office existing outside of Khartoum 4. 300 representatives of the judiciary, prosecutors, police and prison staff and social workers trained in human rights and 47 social workers 5. 82 parliamentarians and legal advisors trained on importance of law reform for child law and women’s law 6. UPR action Plan for the UPR process developed 7. 30% of people report high confidence in and easy access to rule of law institutions overall; 20% women report high confidence; 22% reported easy access (2013) 8. 4 Legal aid network (LAN) organizations and 4 JCCs in Darfur were fully functional and active during 2013 9. Two legal aid desks established in the selected prisons in Darfur but not yet effectively functional 10. There is little knowledge on the alternative dispute resolution mechanisms 11.Limited monitoring visits to support project implementation by staff

target.comment: 1. Two criminal justice forums established at regional level (one in Darfur and one in eastern Sudan) and quarterly meetings held 2. 6 strategic planning sessions provided to selected justice sector institutions 3. 70% of citizens report confidence in and easy access to rule of law institutions 4. 6 refresher courses for GoS prisons officers on human rights approach to prisons management and 6 training courses for newly recruited prisons officers conducted in all five Darfur states for 300 participants 5. 1 underground water tank (250,000 liters) and 1 elevated water tank (40,000 liters) constructed at Shallah Federal Prison in El Fasher to address water needs 6. 6 vocational and livelihood skills training workshops established and tools and equipment for welding and metal works, carpentry, masonry, auto-mechanics, and tailoring procured in 6 Darfur prisons (Shallah Federal Prison in El Fasher; Kheir Khanaga Women Prison in El Fasher; Central Prison in Nyala; Ardamata Prison in El Geneina; Zalingei Prison; and El Daein Prison 7. # senior police management and leadership M/F trained on strategic planning 8. Civilian Oversight Mechanisms drafted through 2 consultations and workshops 9. Special committee on Darfur in place and strategic priorities for Darfur established 10. 200 relevant government officials have improved their human rights knowledge and enhanced the implementation of Sudan obligations under human Rights treaties 11. Progress towards revision of 4 laws (Child Act, Press Act, Criminal Act and law related to women’s rights) 12. Sets of indicators and timelines to monitor UPR implementation progress developed and included into the UPR Action Plan 13. 50% report high confidence overall; 30% women report high confidence; 30% report easy access. 14. Target: 300 clients (30% women) assisted with legal aid counselling at the 8 existing JCCs across Darfur and 150 clients in eastern Sudan 15. 10 NGOs and CBOs participating in access to justice trainings

actual.comment:
1) Overall progress for output 1: improve justice, security and human rights provided by state actors through more effective, equitable and timely protection services: Implementation of activities to improve the capacity of Justice, Security and human Rights Institutions is progressing well. Vocational training were developed and delivered with the participation of various stakeholders including UNAMID, Police and Prison Section with government ministries (Prosecutor, Prison and Police). Implementation of the 5 Year Strategic plan for prison development is progressing well (17F & 113M) prison officers benefited from Human rights approach to prisons management for prison officers. Fair trial and legal aid related principles have been incorporated into training models for prosecutors and lawyers (123F & 267M). Similarly, management and leadership skills, criminal investigation, with focus SGBV were delivered to police officers (8F & 56M). To increase the extension of police service Community policing volunteers training models were delivered with the participation of IDPs, community leaders, women groups, youth (445F & 356M). Special efforts have also been made improve Darfur Transitional Justice institutions to fight impunity and promote reconciliation with a Witness and Victims Protection Strategy along with UNAMID Human Rights Section. Implementation of UPR Recommendations is progressing well. Data collection around the implementation of UPR is showing that 85% of UPR Recommendations have been implemented, with the amendment of Criminal Law, Election Law and the adoption of Human Trafficking Law and Access to Information Law and Regulation of Refugees Law. Access to legal aid and protection for vulnerable groups strengthened
2) Overall progress for Output 2: Access to legal aid and protection for vulnerable groups strengthened : With the goal of scaling up the provision of legal aid and enhance legal awareness efforts in multiple provinces in five Darfur States an

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Output 1 Complaints management infrastructure strengthned
Indicators: 4.1. Mandate of Complaints committee reviewed/modified and Job classification of secretary reclassified as Registrar 4.2: Extent to which workflow design for Case management is completed for entire lifecycle of complaints 4:3: Development of operational policies for complaints management established 4.4: Development of Manuals (tools) for intake, investigations, referrals, reporting, urgent cases, confidentiality, and systemic cases . 4.5: Feasibility study developed/finalized on viable options for automated CM system 4.6: Caseload (quantity) of received is disaggerated equaly on gender baisis 4.7 . Duration of case processing by calaneder days. Output 5: Engagement in Darfur supported
Output 2: Engagement in Darfur supported
Indicators
2. 1: New committee on Darfur established and strategic priorities for Darfur defined 2.2: workshops on joint human rights cooperation framework conducted 23: of meetings of Darfur human rights forum 2.4: of meetings of State human rights sub-forums at the local level to address key human rights concerns
Indicators: output 3 Commissioners and staff capacity to perform respective functions through the delivery of targeted trainings and professional development:
3.1. # of staff trained on new policies and software; protection and promotion 3.2 # operational policies developed covering all areas of NHRI

baseline.comment:
1.1 Complaints Committee established and has begun working, but administrative staff acts as intake officer and registrar 1.2: There is no structured workflow for case management life cycle in SNHRC 1.3: No complaints management manual 1.4: No feasibility study has been conducted 1,5 No automated case management system in place 1.6 Gender disaggregation of caseload is currently 20% female and 80% males cases 1.7 . TBC
Baseline out 2:
2.1: No committee on Darfur established and strategic priorities for Darfur not defined 2.2: No engagement of SNHRC in joint human rights cooperation framework 2.3: Zero 2.4: No systematic engagement or activities in Darfur
Baseline output3:
3.1. Zero staff trained 3.2. Zero operational policy is in place

target.comment:
4.1: Complaints committee reviewed to assumes oversight and governance role; position of registrar established 4.2: Complaints management process flow is designed for entire case management life cycle 4.3: Caseload processing manuals are developed for intake, investigations, referrals, reporting, urgent cases, confidentiality, and systemic cases 4..4 Feasibility study on CM finalized 4.5 Automated case management system installed and in place 4.6 Gender disaggregation of caseload become 50% female and 50% males cases 4.7 . TBE
Targets for Output 2:
2.1: Special committee on Darfur in place and Strategic priorities for Darfur set 2: 2 One workshop on joint human rights cooperation framework 2.3 Four meetings of the Darfur Human Rights Forum with Gos, ACHR, SNHRC, donors, UN agencies, CSOs 2.4: Ten meetings at the local level to address key human rights concerns
Targets for Output 3:
3.1. All staff (112 staff 40% of whom are females ) received training on core operational policies; At least 10 trainings courses conducted on case management. 3.2. TBC (Key internal administrative and operational policies in place)

actual.comment:
Overall progress of output 4: Complaint Management infrastructure strengthened: internal regulations of the Complaints Committee revised with oversight and governance role of the Complaints Committee, with Complaints Manual and standard forms covering the management process for the entire life cycle of a case have been developed. In order to increase the visibility of the SNHRC and of the Complaints Committee in particular, an outreach programme was organized for 70 people, including over 10 members of the media.
Overall Progress of Output 5 Engagement in Darfur: Workshop was organized in Khartoum with representatives from Darfur, UNAMID Human rights Section to establish the new Committee on Darfur and define its road map or strategic plan for the opening of the SNHRC in Darfur, and arrangements are underway to launch the Darfur Branch in December
Overall Progress of output 6: Commissioners and staff capacity to perform respective functions through the delivery of targeted training and professional developed: Significant results have been achieved in developing internal policies. A two-day training for the Commissioners and the staff of the Complaints Committee was held, and 7 operational policies were developed: 1 internal regulation and 3 key operational procedures for the Complaints Committee (as annexes to the Complaints Manual) ; 1 ethics/conflict of interest policy; 1 Staff Recruitment policy; 1 job description template

baseline.comment: Sudan hosts around 171,000 refugees and asylum seekers from a range of countries: Eritrea, Ethiopia, Chad, (CAR), the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Somalia and Syria. Around 92,000 live in eastern Sudan, another 32,000 in Khartoum, and around 45,000 in Darfur. Sudan also has over 90,000 Sudanese in Darfur who were previously refugees in Chad, and have now returned to their country of origin, but not all to their area of origin. Finally, there are also potentially 350,000 individuals of South Sudanese origin (of which around 40,000 reside in Khartoum) who had been living in Sudan prior to secession that did not flee conflict. They have an unclear legal status and so are potentially at risk of statelessness.

baseline.comment: Since 2014, Sudan has witnessed an upsurge in conflict-induced displacement. In order to address the needs of these newly displaced people, as well as those people who have been displaced for a number of years, the protection sector has identified a number of priority areas to guide interventions in 2015. These interventions will be carried out in collaboration with the Government of Sudan, relevant protection institutions and humanitarian organisations.

target.comment:
Output 1: Stocktaking of Sudan Achievements in Implementing MDGs conducted Indicators: 1.1 Extent of progress in developing the Sudan final MDGs report (Scale 1-4) 1 Not started, 2 Very Partially, 3 Partially, 4 Completed). 1.2 Endorsement of the Sudan final MDGs report by stakeholders ( Yes/No)
Targets: 1.1 (4: Completed) Output 2: Advocacy for Positioning SDGs as Base for Development Planning and Policies Delivered Indicators: 2.1 Extent to which Sudan adopted SDGs as base for development planning and policies delivered. Rating scale (1 to 4) 1= Not Adequately, 2= Very Partially, 3=Partially; 4= Largely 2.2 Strategic alignment of all ongoing initiatives with SDGs goals Rating scale (1 to 4) 1= Not Adequately, 2= Very Partially, 3=Partially; 4= Largely
Targets: 2.1 (2= Very Partially) 2.2 (2= Very Partially Output 3: Support to Development of Statistics for MDGs/SDGs Planning, Monitoring and Implementation Provided Indicators: 3.1. Extent of progress in developing states strategies for development of statistics Rating scale (1 to 4) 1= Not achieved 2= Partially achieved 3= Mostly achieved 4= Fully achieved 3.2. % of sectorial strategies for development of statistics which has started being implemented 3.3. Level of progress in implementation of the Joint Programme for the NSDS. Rating scale (1 to 4) 1 = Not achieved 2 = Partially achieved 3 = Mostly achieved 4 = Fully achieved Targets: 3.1 (2 = Partially achieved) 3.2. 50% Sectorial strategies for development of statistics started being implemented 3.3 (2 = Partially achieved Output 4: Support to M&E for Development Planning, Monitoring and Implementation Provided Indicators: 4.1 Scoping and design of country M&E module for SDGs (Yes/No) 4.2 Existence and effectiveness country M&E module for development with mainstreamed SDGs; Rating Scale (1 to 4) 1 = Very Partially, 2 = Partially, 3 = Largely, 4 = Fully
Targets: 4.1 Yes 4.2 (2 = Partially).

actual.comment:
Output 1: Stocktaking of Sudan Achievements in Implementing MDGs conducted Indicators: 1.1 Extent of progress in developing the Sudan final MDGs report (Scale 1-4) 1 Not started, 2 Very Partially, 3 Partially, 4 Completed). 1.2 Endorsement of the Sudan final MDGs report by stakeholders ( Yes/No)
Results: 1.1 (4: Completed)
Output 2: Advocacy for Positioning SDGs as Base for Development Planning and Policies Delivered Indicators: 2.1 Extent to which Sudan adopted SDGs as base for development planning and policies delivered. Rating scale (1 to 4) 1= Not Adequately, 2= Very Partially, 3=Partially; 4= Largely 2.2 Strategic alignment of all ongoing initiatives with SDGs goals Rating scale (1 to 4) 1= Not Adequately, 2= Very Partially, 3=Partially; 4= Largely
Results: 2.1 (2= Very Partially) 2.2 (2= Very Partially
Output 3: Support to Development of Statistics for MDGs/SDGs Planning, Monitoring and Implementation Provided Indicators: 3.1. Extent of progress in developing states strategies for development of statistics Rating scale (1 to 4) 1= Not achieved 2= Partially achieved 3= Mostly achieved 4= Fully achieved 3.2. % of sectorial strategies for development of statistics which has started being implemented 3.3. Level of progress in implementation of the Joint Programme for the NSDS. Rating scale (1 to 4) 1 = Not achieved 2 = Partially achieved 3 = Mostly achieved 4 = Fully achieved Results: 3.1 (2 = Partially achieved) 3.2. 50% Sectorial strategies for development of statistics started being implemented 3.3 (2 = Partially achieved
Output 4: Support to M&E for Development Planning, Monitoring and Implementation Provided Indicators: 4.1 Scoping and design of country M&E module for SDGs (Yes/No) 4.2 Existence and effectiveness country M&E module for development with mainstreamed SDGs; Rating Scale (1 to 4) 1 = Very Partially, 2 = Partially, 3 = Largely, 4 = Fully
Results: 4.1 No 4.2 (1 = Very Partially).
